title: FreesearchR knowledge base
text:
Preface
This book will form the knowledge data base that goes with the FreesearchR project. This will contain a basic introduction to data science and data analysis as a foundation for starting to use the FreesearchR app.
Key motivations for this project are to

lower the barrier to do data analysis
empower clinicians to perform data analysis on own data locally
provide learners with basic knowledge to make informed decisions

The main audience for this project is clinicians, researchers and students with a need for basic analytical tools and knowledge to start interpreting clinical data. The methods used are general and can be used beyond this main audience.
This knowledge database will mainly consist of instructions and descriptions for the FreesearchR app as well as a collection of links and references for recommended further reading and learning.

title: 1  Questions and answers
text:
1.1 Questions and answers
Below we have collected some user questions and answers to help you get started with common tasks.

title: 1  Questions and answers
text:
1.1.1 On summary statistics



But I want to ask a question I want to know to get summary statistics for numeric variable. So how I can get for this program



You can find basic statistics mainly in two places. In the “Prepare” -> “Overview and filter” you can click “Browse observations”. Here you can see basic statistics in the top row for each variable. In the “Evaluate” -> “Characteristics” you can generate a table to see some additional details.
In the sidebar you can choose between “Minimal” or “Extensive” detail level.


1.1.2 On data comparisons



Then what about chi square value to see whether two categories related or not because I was seeing only correlation



When you generate characteristics table, you can choose in sidebare to stratify (or group) the table and then to compare the strata (groups). This will give you relevant comparisons.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3 Getting started with FreesearchR
Below is a simple walk-trough and basic descriptions on the different features of the FreesearchR app.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.1 Launching
The easiest way to get started is to launch the onlie version of the app (click this link). Please be aware not to upload sensitive data in this version as data security can not be guaranteed in this online environment. The app can easily be run from R on your own computer by running the code below (read more on running locally here):

require("pak")
pak::pak("agdamsbo/FreesearchR")
library(FreesearchR)
FreesearchR::launch_FreesearchR()

As a small note, a standalone Windows app version is on the drawing board as well, but no time frame is currently available.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.2 Get started
Once in the app, get started by loading your data. You have three options available for importing data: file upload, REDCap server export and local or sample data.
After choosing a data source nad importing data, you can preview the basic data structure and missing observations, set a threshold to filter data by completeness and further manually specify variables to include for analyses.

3.2.1 File upload
Several data file formats are supported for easy import (csv, txt, xls(x), ods, rds, dta). If importing workbooks (xls(x) or ods), you are prompted to specify sheet(s) to import. If choosing multiple sheets, these are automatically merged by common variable(s), so please make sure that key/ID variables are correctly named identically.


3.2.2 REDCap server export
Export data directly from a REDCap server. You need to first generate an API-token (see these instruction) in REDCap. Make sure you have the necessary rights to do so.
Please don’t store the API-key on your device unless encrypted or in a keyring, as this may compromise data safety. Log in to your REDCap server and retrieve the token when needed.
Type the correct web address of your REDCap server.
The module will validate the information and you can click “Connect”.
This will unfold options to preview your data dictionary (the main database metadata), choose fields/variables to download as well as filtering options.


3.2.3 Local or sample data
When opening the online hosted app, you can load some sample data to try out the app. When running the app locally from R on your own computer, you will find all data frames loaded in your environment here. This extends the possible uses of this app to allow for quick and easy data insights and code generation.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.3 Prepare
This is the panel to prepare data for evaluation and analyses and get a good overview of your data, check data is classed and formatted correctly, perform simple modifications and filter data.

3.3.1 Summary
Here, the data variables can be inspected with a simple visualisation and a few key measures. Also, data filtering is available at two levels:

Data type filtering allows to filter by variable data type
Observations level filtering allow to filter data by variable



3.3.2 Modify
Re-class, rename, and relabel variables. Subset data, create new variables and reorder factor levels. Also, compare the modified dataset to the original and restore the original data.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.4 Evaluate
This panel allows for basic data evaluation.

3.4.1 Characteristics
Create a classical baseline characteristics table with optional data stratification and comparisons.


3.4.2 Correlation matrix
Visualise variable correlations and get suggestions to exclude highly correlated variables.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.5 Visuals
There are a number of plotting options to visualise different aspects of the data.
Below are the available plot types listed.










Data type
Plot type
Description




continuous
Violin plot
A modern alternative to the classic boxplot to visualise data distribution


continuous
Scatter plot
A classic way of showing the association between to variables


continuous
Box plot
A classic way to plot data distribution by groups


dichotomous
Stacked relative barplot
Create relative stacked barplots to show the distribution of categorical levels


dichotomous
Side-by-side barplot
Create side-by-side barplot to show the distribution of categorical levels


dichotomous
Stacked horizontal bars
A classical way of visualising the distribution of an ordinal scale like the modified Ranking Scale and known as Grotta bars


dichotomous
Sankey plot
A way of visualising change between groups


dichotomous
Euler diagram
Generate area-proportional Euler diagrams to display set relationships


categorical
Stacked relative barplot
Create relative stacked barplots to show the distribution of categorical levels


categorical
Side-by-side barplot
Create side-by-side barplot to show the distribution of categorical levels


categorical
Stacked horizontal bars
A classical way of visualising the distribution of an ordinal scale like the modified Ranking Scale and known as Grotta bars


categorical
Sankey plot
A way of visualising change between groups





Export the plots directly from the sidebar with easily adjusted plot dimensions for your next publication.
Also copy the code to generate the plot in your own R-environment and fine tune all the small details.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.6 Regression
This section is only intended for very simple explorative analyses and as a proof-of-concept for now. If you are doing complex regression analyses you should probably just write the code yourself.
Below are the available regression types listed.











Data type
Regression model
Function
Study design




continuous
Linear regression model
stats::lm
cross-sectional


dichotomous
Logistic regression model
stats::glm
cross-sectional


categorical
Ordinal logistic regression model
MASS::polr
cross-sectional






3.6.1 Table
Generate simple regression models and get the results in a nice table. This will also be included in the exported report.
This will generate a combined table with both univariate regression model results for each included variable and a multivariate model with all variables included for explorative analyses.


3.6.2 Plots
Plot the coefficients from the regression models in a forest plot. Choose which model(s) to include.


3.6.3 Model checks
Check model assumptions visually. Supported checks can be chosen.

title: 2  FreesearchR app intro
text:
3.7 Download

3.7.1 Report
Download a nice report with baseline characteristics and regression model results. Choose between MS Word or LibreOffice format.


3.7.2 Data
Export the modified dataset in different formats.


3.7.3 Code
See all the code snippets from the different steps in your data evaluation.

title: 3  Understanding data types
text:
3.1 A clinical data class
Traditionally in R, data is identified by classes, like numeric, integer, double, logical, factor etc. These classes can be a little confusing from a clinical or operational standpoint. In the FreesearchR app, these classes has been simplified and modified to the following data types, that are assigned on a prioritised order like the following:
data_types() |> purrr::imap(\(.x,.i){
  dplyr::bind_cols("type"=.i,.x,.name_repair = "unique_quiet")
  }) |> dplyr::bind_rows() |> 
  setNames(c("Data type","Description","Data classes included")) |> 
  knitr::kable()









Data type
Description
Data classes included




empty
Variable of all NAs
Any class


monotone
Variable with only one unique value
Any class


dichotomous
Variable with only two unique values
Any class


categorical
Factor variable
factor (ordered or unordered)


text
Character variable
character


datetime
Variable of time, date or datetime values
hms, Date, POSIXct and POSIXt


continuous
Numeric variable
numeric, integer or double


unknown
Anything not falling within the previous
Any other class
Categorising data in this way makes sense when making choices on how to evaluate and analyse data. This is used throughout the FreesearchR app to simplify data handling.

title: 4  Options for data visuals
text:
4.1 Basic visualisations
The goal of FreesearchR is to keep things simple. Visuals can get very complicated. We provide a selection of plots, that helps visualise typical clinical and will be enough for most use cases, and for publishing to most journals.
If you want to go further, have a look at these sites with suggestions and sample code for data plotting:

title: 4  Options for data visuals
text:
R Charts: Extensive gallery with great plots
R Graph gallery: Another gallery with great graphs
graphics principles: Easy to follow recommendations for clear visuals.

title: 5  missingness
text: 5.1 Considering missing observations

title: 5  missingness
text:
5.1.1 Further reading
The authors behind the {finalfit}-package have shared a very comprehensive article on what to do and think about missing observations in your data. Please have a look here.

title: 6  Randomised clinical trial in stroke
text:
6.1 A clinical trial on neuroprotection in stroke
This case study will be based on the study “Neuroregeneration and Vascular Protection by Citalopram in Acute Ischemic Stroke (TALOS)”.(K. L. Kraglund et al. 2018)
We will not be able to include all data from this trial, but key tables and figures based on annonymised data from the trial included in the FreesearchR app will be used. These data are published for educational purposes in the “stRoke” package, which also includes a few tools for clinical stroke trials.(Damsbo 2023)
The TALOS trial was a randomised trial, with a predefined analysis plan and a published protocol.(K. Kraglund et al. 2015) As the trial was randomised, the main analyses where
crumbs: 6  Randomised clinical trial in stroke

title: 6  Randomised clinical trial in stroke
text:
6.1.1 Load the data
Start of by launching the FreesearchR app (click this link).

Go to the “Get started” tab,
under “Choose your data source”, select “Local or sample data”,
then under “Select data source”, select “stRoke”, and
then under “Select a dataset”, select “trial”.

This should load the data, and you can press the “Quick overview” to preview the data classes and missing values.
In the section “Select variables for final import”, you can decide to set a missingness threshold and specify variables to initially include. Leaves these options at the default for now. For this exercise, just include all variables.


6.1.2 Baseline characteristics
Having loaded the relevant dataset, we will go straight to generating a classic table for overview of the variables, typically what is included in papers as a Table 1.

Click the “Evaluate” panel and
select the “Characteristics” sub-panel in the dropdown.

This is the section, where the characteristics panel is generated.
In the sidebar

Under “Select variable to stratify baseline”, select “active” to stratify by active trial treatment, and
then click “Evaluate”, wait a second and have a look at the table generated.

The table can be exported in a document format.

Go to the “Download” panel at the top,
under “Report”, choose the desired document format (MS Word or LibreOffice), and
click “Download report”.

This will generate the report and it will get downloaded to your device. Find it in your downloads folder.


6.1.3 Visualise the classic outcome
The modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score has been used as the main outcome for a large number stroke trials.(“Tissue Plasminogen Activator for Acute Ischemic Stroke” 1995; Berkhemer et al. 2015; Blauenfeldt et al. 2023) The TALOS trial also used the mRS, but did not include a graph to show the distribution. Let’s create that graph now then:

Go to “Visuals”, and
select “mrs_6” as the “Response variable” to see plotting options, and
select “Stacked horizontal bars” and
select “active” as the secondary variable to stratify by trial treatment, then
click “Plot” to view the results.

To export the plot

Click the “Download” sidebar section to unfold the download options,
specify the details and select file format, and
click “Download”.

Open the plot locally to verify the results.


6.1.4 Now its time for experimentation
The above instructions are intended to introduce some of the functionality of the FreesearchR app. Please review the sections to experiment to explore the functions, but also to explore the data you are using. Here are some questions to think about:

What is the median age for men? And for women?
How is the distribution of of mRS score at 1 month?
How is the distribution of mRS score at 6 months grouped by sex?
In the trial introducing IVT treatment(“Tissue Plasminogen Activator for Acute Ischemic Stroke” 1995), several outcome scales were used and binned. How would this be done with the FreesearchR app?
…





Berkhemer, Olvert A., Puck S. S. Fransen, Debbie Beumer, Lucie A. van den Berg, Hester F. Lingsma, Albert J. Yoo, Wouter J. Schonewille, et al. 2015. “A Randomized Trial of Intraarterial Treatment for Acute Ischemic Stroke.” New England Journal of Medicine 372 (1): 11–20. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMoa1411587.


Blauenfeldt, Rolf Ankerlund, Niels Hjort, Jan Brink Valentin, Anne-Mette Homburg, Boris Modrau, Birgitte Forsom Sandal, Martin Faurholdt Gude, et al. 2023. “Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Acute Stroke.” JAMA 330 (13): 1236. https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.2023.16893.


Damsbo, Andreas Gammelgaard. 2023. Agdamsbo/stRoke: stRoke 23.6.3. Zenodo. https://doi.org/10.5281/ZENODO.8013980.


Kraglund, Kristian Lundsgaard, Janne Kaergaard Mortensen, Andreas Gammelgaard Damsbo, Boris Modrau, Sofie Amalie Simonsen, Helle Klingenberg Iversen, Morten Madsen, Erik Lerkevang Grove, Søren Paaske Johnsen, and Grethe Andersen. 2018. “Neuroregeneration and Vascular Protection by Citalopram in Acute Ischemic Stroke (TALOS).” Stroke 49 (11): 2568–76. https://doi.org/10.1161/strokeaha.117.020067.


Kraglund, Kristian, Janne Mortensen, Erik Grove, Sren Paaske Johnsen, and Grethe Andersen. 2015. “TALOS: A Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial to Test the Effects of Citalopram in Patients with Acute Stroke.” International Journal of Stroke 10 (6): 985–87. https://doi.org/10.1111/ijs.12485.


“Tissue Plasminogen Activator for Acute Ischemic Stroke.” 1995. New England Journal of Medicine 333 (24): 1581–88. https://doi.org/10.1056/nejm199512143332401.
crumbs: 6  Randomised clinical trial in stroke

title: 7  Overlapping measures
text:
7.1 Overlapping measures
For the following case study on using the FreesearchR tool, the following article will be used as an example: Damsbo et al. (2020).
This article includes a table of baseline characteristics, a regression table and an Euler plot of overlapping markers of poor mental health after stroke. Based on an anonymised dataset, the basics of each of these elements will be recreated in the following.

title: 7  Overlapping measures
text:
7.1.1 The Euler plot
The Euler plot is an area-accurate plot of overlapping features. This can be used to visualise how patients suffer from several diseases or how symptoms of mental health are overlapping.
Plotting the Euler plot is based on dichotomised categorical variables (2 levels). In the FreesearchR app, categorical variables can be created from continuous data.


7.1.2 Load the data
Start of by launching the FreesearchR app (click this link).

Go to the “Get started” tab,
under “Choose your data source”, select “Local or sample data”,
then under “Select data source”, select “stRoke”, and
then under “Select a dataset”, select “trial”.

This should load the data, and you can press the “Quick overview” to preview the data classes and missing values.
In the section “Select variables for final import”, you can decide to set a missingness threshold and specify variables to initially include. Leaves these options at the default for now. For this exercise, just include all variables.


7.1.3 Baseline characteristics
See “Baseline characteristics” on how to create a baseline characteristics table.


7.1.4 Plotting
Now on to the plotting. I will start by showing how to visualise the overlapping features of hypertension, diabetes and living alone:

Open the “Visuals” panel,
select “hypertension” as the “Response variable” to see plotting options, and
select “Euler diagram” and
select “diabetes” and “cohabitation” as “Additional variables”,
click “Plot”.


7.1.4.1 Creating categorical variables
If you want to create new dichotomous (2-level categorical) variables from continuous data, then follow the below steps (as an exaple the “mfi_6” variable will be used):

Go to “Prepare” -> “Edit and create data”, the
select “New factor” (factor is the technical term for a categorical variable), and then
in the pop-up window, under “Variable to cut”, select “mfi_6”,
keep the “Method” “fixed”, and choose “2” under “Number of breaks” to create a categorical variable with 2 levels.
Select the cut-off between the two levels to 12 for the “mfi_6” variable, and then
click “Create factor variable”.

A new variable called “mfi_6_cut” is now created. Repeat the above steps for other variables you want to cut.


7.1.4.2 (Re)ordering categorical variables
Some scoring systems are designed to have a higher score correspond to worse outcome and others are opposite. To specify the order of the categorical levels and allow for correct plotting with the Euler plot (the plots the first level), follow these steps:

While in the same panel (“Prepare” -> “Edit and create data”), click the “Reorder factor levels”, and
order the levels with the first level at the top (drag in the small 3x3 dot grid to the left of the level names), and then
click “Update factor variable”




7.1.5 Now its time for experimentation

Try create categorical variables from the age variable to create a baseline table grouped by age below or above 70.
Create an Euler diagram of age (below/above 70), cohabitation and male sex.
Create and Euler diagram of MFI, MDI (cut-off at 20) and WHO (cut-off at 17). Please note the the WHO should range from 0-100, but the included variable is scaled down by a factor of 4 and ranges 0-25.
…





Damsbo, Andreas Gammelgaard, Kristian Lundsgaard Kraglund, Henriette Nørmølle Buttenschøn, Søren Paaske Johnsen, Grethe Andersen, and Janne Kaergaard Mortensen. 2020. “Predictors for Wellbeing and Characteristics of Mental Health After Stroke.” Journal of Affective Disorders 264 (March): 358–64. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jad.2019.12.032.

title: 8  Further learning
text:
8.1 Where to go next
The FreesearchR project is not affiliated with the listed references below unless stated.
Exercism is a great place to start for open languages (R, Python, Julia or something more exotic), where everything can run in the browser and you don’t need to download anything. You can track your progress and get hints.
